parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across Mediterranean studies, cover crops showed mixed effects on soil water.
[Statement 2]: Some studies found lower soil water with winter cover crops, while others found no difference or higher water in some comparisons.
[Statement 3]: Several studies reported cover crops reduced water loss via drainage, runoff, or evaporation.
[Statement 4]: One study reported higher drainage losses under cover crops in some comparisons.
[Statement 5]: Cover crops reduced herbicide leaching in one study.
[Statement 6]: Multiple studies reported that cover crops reduced nitrate leaching.
[Statement 7]: One study noted less ammonium and dissolved carbon in runoff under cover crops.
[Statement 8]: One study noted more phosphorus in runoff under cover crops.
[Statement 9]: One study noted less suspended sediment in runoff in some comparisons under cover crops.
[Statement 10]: Soil structure and nutrient retention improved under cover crops in randomized, replicated studies.
[Statement 11]: Cover crops resulted in increases in soil carbon.
[Statement 12]: In several studies, cover crops increased nitrogen and carbon.
[Statement 13]: Some European studies found no marked change in soil organic matter when using cover crops.
[Statement 14]: Replicated, controlled studies from Spain, Italy, France, and Israel reported lower crop yields in some comparisons when using cover crops.
[Statement 15]: Replicated, controlled studies from Spain, Italy, France, and Israel reported higher crop yields in some comparisons when using cover crops.
[Statement 16]: Some studies reported inconsistent differences in crop yields, and several cases showed no differences.
[Statement 17]: Crop quality was often unchanged when cover crops were used.
[Statement 18]: Studies found that legume winter cover crops were associated with higher cash crop yields than non-legumes in Italy and Spain.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In Mediterranean studies comparing tillage systems, reduced tillage often increased weed abundance compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 2]: Seven replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy, Lebanon, Spain, and Turkey reported more weeds under reduced tillage than conventional tillage in some or all comparisons.
[Statement 3]: One study comparing reduced tillage to conventional tillage also reported fewer weeds in some comparisons.
[Statement 4]: One Italian study found similar weed numbers between reduced tillage and conventional tillage.
[Statement 5]: Studies from Spain and Turkey reported similar numbers of weed species under reduced versus conventional tillage.
[Statement 6]: Another study detected shifts in weed community composition under reduced tillage.
[Statement 7]: When comparing no tillage versus conventional tillage, evidence from Italy and Spain showed more weeds under no tillage in some comparisons.

[Statement 9]: A study from Lebanon found similar weed numbers when comparing no tillage to conventional tillage.
[Statement 10]: Regarding weed species, one Italian study found more species under no tillage compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 11]: Other Italian and Spanish studies found similar weed species numbers when comparing no tillage to conventional tillage.
[Statement 12]: Comparing no tillage to reduced tillage, four replicated, controlled studies from Italy, Lebanon, and Spain found fewer weeds under no tillage in some or all comparisons.
[Statement 13]: Two of the four replicated, controlled studies also found more weeds under no tillage compared to reduced tillage in some comparisons.
[Statement 14]: Other studies comparing no tillage to reduced tillage reported either more weeds under no tillage or no difference in weed numbers.
[Statement 15]: Regarding weed species, one Spanish study found fewer species under no tillage compared to reduced tillage.
[Statement 16]: Two studies from Italy and Spain found similar numbers of weed species when comparing no tillage to reduced tillage.

[Statement 2]: A replicated, paired, site comparison found more natural enemies in hedgerows themselves compared to weedy edges in some comparisons.
[Statement 3]: The site comparison also found a higher proportion of pest eggs parasitized in tomato fields with hedgerows, but only up to 100 m into the crop.
[Statement 4]: Studies on adding compost to soil reported similar ratios of natural enemies to pests in plots with or without added compost.
[Statement 5]: Studies on adding compost to soil reported similar percentages of pests consumed by natural enemies in plots with or without added compost.
[Statement 6]: Natural enemy numbers were not measured in studies where compost was added to the soil.
[Statement 7]: In studies about using organic fertilizer instead of inorganic, natural enemy numbers were not studied.
[Statement 8]: In studies about excluding grazers, natural enemy numbers were not studied.

key: _gpt-5__What actions can be taken to increase the number of natural enemies for pest regulation on Mediterranean farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A replicated, controlled study from Spain found more pollinators on coriander flowers next to planted flower strips than next to unplanted field margins.
[Statement 2]: Replicated studies from Spain and Italy reported that some planted flower species were more attractive to pollinators than other planted flower species.
[Statement 3]: Studies found that planting more flower species sometimes increased pollinator numbers and sometimes decreased pollinator numbers.
[Statement 4]: In Italy, bee numbers increased over time when three or six flower species were planted but decreased when nine flower species were planted.
[Statement 5]: Replicated, paired site comparisons from the USA found higher crop visitation rates by native bees next to planted hedgerows compared to unplanted edges.
[Statement 6]: The same USA studies did not find higher crop visitation rates by honey bees or syrphid flies next to planted hedgerows compared to unplanted edges.
[Statement 7]: Another study found no difference in bee visitation next to planted edges.
[Statement 8]: Multiple replicated studies from the USA found more bee species in fields with hedgerows or within hedgerows than in fields or edges without hedgerows.
[Statement 9]: Some USA studies found more syrphid fly species or individuals in fields with hedgerows than in fields without hedgerows.
[Statement 10]: One study found fewer ground-nesting bees in planted hedgerows than in unplanted edges.
[Statement 11]: Implementation findings for hedgerows indicated there were more bee species in older hedgerows than in younger hedgerows.
[Statement 12]: Implementation findings for hedgerows sometimes indicated more syrphid fly species in older than younger hedgerows.
[Statement 13]: In old hedgerows, more bee species were found on native plants than on non-native plants.

key: _gpt-5__How does planting flowers compare to planting hedgerows for supporting pollinators on Mediterranean farmland?
